body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#23462](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23462) (test: Enable SC2046 and SC2086 shellcheck rules by hebasto)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
Hi @4D617278, would you mind squashing your commits as described in [these guidelines](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits)?

<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->
🐙 This pull request conflicts with the target branch and [needs rebase](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#rebasing-changes).

<sub>Want to unsubscribe from rebase notifications on this pull request? Just convert this pull request to a "draft".</sub>
./ci/lint/06_script.sh: test/lint/commit-script-check.sh: /bin/env: bad interpreter: No such file or directory
I made changes according to developer notes here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/developer-notes.md#shebang
Missing expected shebang "#!/usr/bin/env bash" or "#!/bin/sh" in test/lint/commit-script-check.sh
Missing the `/usr` -- not everyone has merged `/usr`. If  you're changing to to env, probably should also change it to bash as well to avoid getting weird incompatibilities?
I changed it back to #!/bin/sh in a later commit

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,10 +24,16 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        echo "Script: $SCRIPT"
+        SEDREGEX="^([^#'\"\v]|('[^'\v]*'|\"[^\"\v]*\"))*?(?<![a-z\d])sed(?1)*?-i(?:\.\w+)?[\h,]*(?2)[^#'\"\v]*(?2)"
body: This seems a bit hard to read and impossible to maintain without comments if this should ever fail. I'd say that a simple prompt like "If you are using sed, make sure to not use bsd sed syntax" on failure is sufficient.

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,10 +24,16 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        echo "Script: $SCRIPT"
+        SEDREGEX="^([^#'\"\v]|('[^'\v]*'|\"[^\"\v]*\"))*?(?<![a-z\d])sed(?1)*?-i(?:\.\w+)?[\h,]*(?2)[^#'\"\v]*(?2)"
body: So you don't need me to check for sed bsd syntax or you want the regex to be simpler? I can increase false positives but increase readability and revert to an older commit.

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,10 +24,16 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        echo "Script: $SCRIPT"
+        SEDREGEX="^([^#'\"\v]|('[^'\v]*'|\"[^\"\v]*\"))*?(?<![a-z\d])sed(?1)*?-i(?:\.\w+)?[\h,]*(?2)[^#'\"\v]*(?2)"
body: Or should I add comments to explain the regex better?

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,10 +24,16 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        echo "Script: $SCRIPT"
+        SEDREGEX="^([^#'\"\v]|('[^'\v]*'|\"[^\"\v]*\"))*?(?<![a-z\d])sed(?1)*?-i(?:\.\w+)?[\h,]*(?2)[^#'\"\v]*(?2)"
body: I am not sure myself, but I think I'd rather not do the check. It just seems too fragile, especially with the non-greedy regex, which often isn't implemented correctly in regex engines. And how would we check that the `grep --perl-regexp` is using the right regex engine, and not maybe a BSD regex engine? Add another check ...?

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,10 +24,16 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        echo "Script: $SCRIPT"
+        SEDREGEX="^([^#'\"\v]|('[^'\v]*'|\"[^\"\v]*\"))*?(?<![a-z\d])sed(?1)*?-i(?:\.\w+)?[\h,]*(?2)[^#'\"\v]*(?2)"
body: Ok, how about I just grep for sed without any regular expressions then? Do you want me to undo my commits or to just add a new one?

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,6 +24,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        if echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"; then
+            echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+            echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: Would be better to only print this warning if the check fails, no?

diff_hunk:
@@ -24,6 +24,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
     if git rev-list -n 1 --pretty="%s" $commit | grep -q "^scripted-diff:"; then
         git checkout --quiet $commit^ || exit
         SCRIPT="$(git rev-list --format=%b -n1 $commit | sed '/^-BEGIN VERIFY SCRIPT-$/,/^-END VERIFY SCRIPT-$/{//!b};d')"
+        if echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"; then
+            echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+            echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: With "check" I mean "script evaluation"

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body:
I would have expected a generic warning that the command failed, maybe something more like:

```sh
if ! (eval "$SCRIPT"); then
    echo "Warning: Script failed (non-zero exit code)"
    if echo "$SCRIPT" | grep -q "sed"; then
        echo "Suggestion: did you use BSD sed syntax?"
        echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
    fi
fi
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body:
sed doesn't have an exit code for "error", so checking the exit code wouldn't work either way.


```
$ sed -i -e 's/FOOBAR/foobar/g' ./src/init.cpp && echo $?
0

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: "sed -i '' -e 's/FOOBAR/foobar/g' ./src/init.cpp && echo $?" results in no output for me since the sed command fails and the "echo $?" command is not executed but "sed -i -e 's/FOOBAR/foobar/g' ./src/init.cpp" does in fact work. I think this is because "sed -i -e 's/FOOBAR/foobar/g' ./src/init.cpp" is a legitimate sed command, it just doesn't cause any changes since FOOBAR is not present in the file.

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: In the OpenBSD 6.9 man pages for sed, it states EXIT STATUS The sed utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: failing to replace is not an error

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: The line "git --no-pager diff --exit-code $commit && echo "OK" || (echo "Failed"; false) || RET=1" should check if the script failed to change anything, do you want to check each command and error if if has no change?

diff_hunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,10 @@ for commit in $(git rev-list --reverse $1); do
         else
             echo "Running script for: $commit"
             echo "$SCRIPT"
-            (eval "$SCRIPT")
+            if ! (eval "$SCRIPT") && (echo "$SCRIPT" | grep --quiet "sed"); then
+                echo "Warning: do not use BSD sed syntax"
+                echo "Example: sed -i '' 's/foo/bar/' filename (Bad)"
body: Do you want to not check for non zero exit codes but only check if the output of the script is the same as the commit?
